title: When an Abortion Story Is Told as a Caper, Thriller or Farce
abstract: As Roe falls, new works including a documentary, a feature film and a comedy show disrupt the taboos and clichés around abortion.
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
Oh God, a Show About Abortion (Play)

multimedia.caption: “The Janes,” an HBO documentary about an underground operation helping women seeking abortions prior to the Roe v. Wade decision, has a surprisingly buoyant feel, our critic writes.
“The Janes,” an HBO documentary about an underground operation helping women seeking abortions prior to the Roe v. Wade decision, has a surprisingly buoyant feel, our critic writes.

title: Beyoncé’s ‘Break My Soul’ and the Long Tail of ‘Show Me Love’
abstract: The ubiquitous 1992 remix of Robin S.’s song has endured in samples and covers. Its writers’ names appeared in the credits for Beyoncé’s track, were quickly removed and then restored again.

multimedia.caption: The first single from Beyoncé’s upcoming album, “Renaissance,” is a clubby track called “Break My Soul.”
The first single from Beyoncé’s upcoming album, “Renaissance,” is a clubby track called “Break My Soul.”

title: Returning to the Scene
abstract: “Only Murders in the Building” is the latest series to explore the mystery: Does a good first season always need a sequel?
des_facet: Only Murders in the Building (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top left, Steve Martin, Martin Short and Selena Gomez in a scene from Season 2 of “Only Murders in the Building,” whose first season was a low-key delight of 2021.

abstract: More than three years after the Los Angeles rapper was shot and killed, the trial of Eric Holder Jr., the accused gunman, is nearing its conclusion.

abstract: In honor of Austin Butler’s performance in the Baz Luhrmann biopic, we ranked 10 of the best — and worst — Presleys to grace the silver screen.

title: William Herschel Is Famous for Science. What About His Music?
abstract: The accomplished astronomer was, one historian said, “the Einstein of his time.” But before he surveyed the sky, he was a prolific musician.

multimedia.caption: William Herschel (1738-1822) discovered Uranus, infrared radiation and moons of Saturn. But until he was 44, he was also a tireless freelance musician.
William Herschel (1738-1822) discovered Uranus, infrared radiation and moons of Saturn. But until he was 44, he was also a tireless freelance musician.

title: A Grand Old Art Fair Returns, to a World That Has Changed
abstract: At TEFAF Maastricht, a sense of resumed normalcy was tempered by an awareness that the pandemic has profoundly altered the business of selling centuries-old art.
org_facet: TEFAF (The European Fine Art Fair Stichting)

multimedia.caption: Visitors attending the 35th edition of The European Fine Art Fair, or TEFAF, on Sunday in Maastricht, the Netherlands.
Visitors attending the 35th edition of The European Fine Art Fair, or TEFAF, on Sunday in Maastricht, the Netherlands.

title: ‘Chains’ Review: Drab Lives, but Dreaming of More
abstract: A young boarder’s plan to make a new life in Australia unsettles a staid British family in Elizabeth Baker’s 1909 play, revived by the Mint Theater Company.

multimedia.caption: Laakan McHardy, left, and Jeremy Beck portray a contentedly married London couple challenged by their boarder’s rash decision in the Mint Theater Company production of “Chains.”
Laakan McHardy, left, and Jeremy Beck portray a contentedly married London couple challenged by their boarder’s rash decision in the Mint Theater Company production of “Chains.”
Laakan McHardy, left, and Jeremy Beck portray a contentedly married London couple challenged by their boarder’s rash decision in the Mint Theater Company production of “Chains.”

title: Sam Gilliam, Abstract Artist of Drape Paintings, Dies at 88
abstract: A brilliant colorist, he hung his canvases from ceilings in great curves and loops, or pinned them, gathered, to walls, taking his medium into three dimensions.

multimedia.caption: Sam Gilliam in 2018 at his studio in Washington. “My work is as political as it is formal,” he once said.
multimedia.copyright: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Sam Gilliam in 2018 at his studio in Washington. “My work is as political as it is formal,” he once said.

title: ‘Endangered’ Review: When Journalism Becomes Imperiled
abstract: A new documentary from Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady explores threats to press freedom, but not with the focus this global issue deserves.

abstract: An expectant mother and a male birthing counselor learn to get along in this dry, refreshingly candid comedy.

title: The Dystopia Has Just Arrived
abstract: Davey Davis’s new novel, “X,” is a queer noir set in a near-future world full of inexplicable violence, “exported” undesirables and an encyclopedia’s worth of sexual deviance.

title: Is That Steph Curry … or a Work of Art?
abstract: This Instagram account will change how you see basketball.

title: ‘Jimmy Kimmel Live’ Guest Host Chelsea Handler Chides the Supreme Court
abstract: “At this point I’d probably have more rights if my vagina was an AR-15,” Handler mused on Monday.

abstract: Subscribers in the United States will lose a classic ’90s rom-com among other delightful titles. Watch these while you can.

title: Poisonous Gas Leak in Jordan Kills at Least 10 People
abstract: Public security officials said a gas tanker sprung a leak while being transported, and video showed a tanker being dropped as it was moved and emitting a large cloud of yellow smoke.

multimedia.caption: The toxic gas explosion in Jordan’s Aqaba port, in a still image from CCTV footage broadcast by Jordan’s public broacaster Al-Mamlaka TV on Monday.

title: Ralph Fiennes to Star in Play About Robert Moses at the Shed
abstract: The production of “Straight Line Crazy,” by David Hare, will begin preview performances Oct. 18 and have a nine-week run.

title: In This Story Collection, the Dead Are Served Up Hot-Pot Style
abstract: Sayaka Murata’s “Life Ceremony” explores the grotesque and the intersections of extremes.

title: Drake’s ‘Honestly, Nevermind’ Is His 11th No. 1 Album
abstract: The dance-oriented surprise release debuts with the equivalent of 204,000 sales — the streaming star’s lowest opening-week tally for a studio album.

multimedia.caption: No Drake studio album has begun with fewer than half a million equivalents since “What a Time to Be Alive,” a mixtape with the rapper Future from 2015.

title: Documenting India’s Distinctive Birdhouses
abstract: For seven years, a photographer based in Delhi has collected images of ornamental structures known as chabutras. Here are some of his favorites.

multimedia.caption: A large birdhouse in the village of Sinugra, in the western state of Gujarat. The structure not only houses birds but also has space to store their grains.

abstract: Angela Hanks’s new comedy is set in Santa Fe, N.M., where five women of color have traveled for some fancy R&R laced with New Age spirituality.

title: Wagner’s Early Operas Shouldn’t Be Mere Curiosities
abstract: A survey at Oper Leipzig provides an opportunity to reassess the youthful efforts that have been excluded from the composer’s canon.

multimedia.caption: Stefan Vinke in the title role of “Rienzi,” Richard Wagner's first successful opera, at Oper Leipzig in Germany.

title: Patrick Adams, Master of New York’s Underground Disco Scene, Dies at 72
abstract: He produced, arranged or engineered many of the era’s biggest nightclub hits, even if his records rarely got much play on the radio.

multimedia.caption: Patrick Adams speaking at the Red Bull Music Academy in New York in 2013. Despite his low profile, he left his fingerprints everywhere as a record producer, engineer and arranger.

title: In This Novel of Female Friendship, Birds of a Feather Drift Apart
abstract: The stylish, reckless heroines of Carlene Bauer’s “Girls They Write Songs About” bond over their similarities, until one decides to settle down.

title: Gloria Allen, Transgender Activist Who Ran a Charm School, Dies at 76
abstract: She overcame a life of intolerance and abuse to teach style, etiquette and life lessons to young transgender people who were at risk.

title: On Broadway, One Show Decides to Keep Masks. No, It’s Not ‘Phantom.’
abstract: “American Buffalo,” at Circle in the Square, is sticking with masking till it closes, July 10, citing the “proximity of the audience to the actors” and “the staging in the round.”

multimedia.caption: From left: Sam Rockwell, Darren Criss and Laurence Fishburne in “American Buffalo” at the Circle in the Square Theater. The show announced the change in policy in a news release, citing “the close proximity of the audience to the actors.”

From left: Sam Rockwell, Darren Criss and Laurence Fishburne in “American Buffalo” at the Circle in the Square Theater. The show announced the change in policy in a news release, citing “the close proximity of the audience to the actors.”

title: F.B.I. Raids Orlando Museum and Removes Basquiat Paintings
abstract: All 25 works in the museum’s Jean-Michel Basquiat exhibition were seized by the F.B.I. An affidavit called into question their origin and their authenticity.
byline: By Brett Sokol and Matt Stevens

multimedia.caption: Law enforcement personnel outside the Orlando Museum of Art on Friday, June 24. Earlier, F.B.I. agents seized 25 paintings said by the museum to be by Jean-Michel Basquiat following questions raised about their authenticity.
multimedia.copyright: Willie J. Allen Jr./Orlando Sentinel, via Associated Press

multimedia.caption: Law enforcement personnel outside the Orlando Museum of Art on Friday, June 24. Earlier, F.B.I. agents seized 25 paintings said by the museum to be by Jean-Michel Basquiat following questions raised about their authenticity.

title: Review: Pacific Northwest Ballet Finally Makes It Back to New York
abstract: On Thursday’s mixed bill, Ulysses Dove’s “Dancing on the Front Porch of Heaven” was the most arresting and emotionally resonant work.

title: Immersed in ‘Stranger Things,’ Then Strolling to Beckett
abstract: Our writer checked out two very different experiences in New York. In Netflix’s TV re-creation, you fight Demogorgons. In “Cascando,” you walk off your existential angst.

multimedia.caption: “Stranger Things: The Experience” at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn immerses you in a battle with monsters.

title: Baxter Black, Who Elevated Cowboy Poetry to Folk Art, Dies at 77
abstract: His wide-ranging work, including books, speeches and regular appearances on NPR, celebrated cowpokes, feed lots and life on the range.

multimedia.caption: The cowboy poet Baxter Black, standing, was grand marshal of the National Western Stock Show parade in Denver in 2009. He said his audience on NPR, where he delivered commentary for more than a decade, was different from his “cowy” audience out west.

The cowboy poet Baxter Black, standing, was grand marshal of the National Western Stock Show parade in Denver in 2009. He said his audience on NPR, where he delivered commentary for more than a decade, was different from his “cowy” audience out west.

title: Documenta Was a Whole Vibe. Then a Scandal Killed the Buzz.
abstract: Accusations that an image was antisemitic broke the mood at a daring festival of experiments. This year’s Documenta deserves a closer look, our critic says.

multimedia.caption: Two visitors skating inside a work called “Skate to Milk” by the Baan Norg Collaborative Arts and Culture, in the Documenta Halle in Kassel, Germany.
multimedia.copyright: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
